channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: #121 - Advent is getting closer
item.description:
Hi there,

Christmas is getting close and before that there is the tradition of creating Advent calendars. In the Perl world it means a series of articles, one article every day in the 3 weeks leading up t Christmas. It is a community project so you can also contribute an article or two. See the advent section for more details.

Enjoy!

item.title: We're Hiring Perl Software Developers - Grant Street Group
item.description:
We're a growing software company using open source software/modern Perl practices to build innovative e-payment, auction, and tax collection web applications.
We're looking for talented, motivated professionals committed to flawless work and customer service.
Email resume: 106686-CS-6734@grantstreet.hrmdirect.com

item.title: Back-End Blacksmith
item.description: Do you take pride in your craft and want to have fun() at the same time? Are you a geek? Join the team of iwantmyname from anywhere.

item.title: Padre 1.00 has been released
item.description: Without a lot of fanfare Padre, the Perl IDE has reached it 1.00 release. Available on a CPAN near you.

item.title: Perl Redis Mailing List
item.description: Damien Krotkine became the maintainer of the Redis Perl module and started his reign by creating a mailing list for the Redis Perl users and developers.

item.title: The Stratopan Beta Is Here
item.description: Jeffrey Ryan Thalhammer has opened the gates of Stratopan. (You might recall, it is the cloud-hosted version Pinto, that gives you control over all your Perl-dependencies so they will be upgrade only when you want it. There is also a promise to get unlimited access to Stratopan for life if you sign up soon. I already have an account.

item.title: Perl Catalyst Request for Advent Season Articles!
item.description: John Napiorkowski calls upon the Catalyst user to submit articles for the Catalyst Advent Calendar.

item.title: Perl Advent Calendar
item.description: Ricardo Signes is working on the Perl Advent Calendar 2013. See the submission FAQ if you are interested in writing an article.

item.title: Dancer advent calendar 2013
item.description: David Precious put out a call for help with the Perl Dancer Advent calendar.

item.title: Windows Shell to Perl Program
item.description: JT Smith writes about the MadMongers meeting where they took a bat file (a Windows shell script) and converted it to a Perl script. It became much longer, so besides having fun, I am not sure what is the advantage here. Unless they plan to wrap some of the functionality in modules so they become reusable and then the actual script becomes short again.

item.title: Don't Get Bent Out of Shape About Being Cross Platform
item.description: Timm Murray, who came out from the Wumpus Cave just to attend the MadMongers meeting, has his own opinion on how much one should invest in turning a script to be platform independent. Especially when there is no immediate need to run the script on other platforms.

item.title: CPAN Testers Summary - Nov 2013 - Pandemonium
item.description: Highlight: the server upgrade is now complete! Test reports are flowing again! - Thanks Barbie!

item.title: Porting Test::Class to the p5-mop
item.description: Ovid has reimplemented Test::Class::Moose as Test::Class::MOP

item.title: A Stratopan quick start user guide
item.description: Now that Stratopan is out in public beta, David Farrell has quickly created a start-up guide with screenshots and explanation.

item.title: Context and the Comma Operator
item.description: Apparently I missed the Tiny Code Quiz Ovid posted last week, but now chromatic took upon the task to try to explain the seemingly (?) unexpected behavior of perl.

item.title: Larry Wall: 5 Programming Languages Everyone Should Know
item.description: 6:13 minutes - part of the BigThink interview.

item.title: Introduction to the Perl Data Language (PDL)
item.description: 51:22 min talk by David Mertens giving some 'simple' (as in simple astrophysics :) example and then a bunch of resource to make it easier to get started. The approach is interesting as he keeps telling why is it better to use PDL than C, but only once does he mention the advantages of PDL over pure Perl.

item.title: The way to write Ruby + Middleman application with Perl.
item.description: Middleman is ruby web framework that makes developing stand-alone websites simple. Yuki Kimoto shows an example using Mojolicious. One of the commenters point to similar solution in Dancer, and yet another commenter points to Poet which is modern web framework for Mason developers.

item.title: How to have several Catalyst apps behind one Apache server
item.description: Tara L Andrews uses Plack::Middleware::ReverseProxyPath and a shell script to solve this.

item.title: Marpa's Advantages
item.description: Ron Savage has published the 2nd chapter of his Marpa Papers.

item.title: moving my homedir into the 21st century
item.description: Ricardo Signes tells us about the pair programming session he had with Ingy dÃ¶t Net and Frew Schmidt, and how it lead him to switch from 'screen' to 'tmux'. He also talks about the dotfile manager he has started to use.

item.title: Multi dimensional hashes in Perl
item.description: Perl only has one-dimensional hashes, but each value in a has can be a reference to another hash. Or an array. This, together with auto-vivification allows the creation of very flexible data structures.

item.title: Nordic Perl Workshop 2013
item.description: November 23, 2013, Copenhagen, Denmark

item.title: London Perl Workshop (LPW 2013)
item.description: Saturday 30th November 2013 at Westminster University

item.title: German Perl Workshop (GPW 2014)
item.description: March 26-28, 2014, Hannover, Germany

item.title: YAPC::NA 2014
item.description: June 23â€“25, 2014, Orlando FL
